ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with this course compared to others you have taken was:
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
How would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other F&ES courses you have taken?
Given the course objectives, the level of intellectual challenge of the material covered was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned to use biophysical and ecological features to read the landscape and convey what I read to landowners.
I learned the geology, soils, and hydrology of New England.
New England plant ID and land use history; forest surveying techniques; client engagement; management plan creation.

narratives.question_text: How well did the knowledge, skills, and insights gained in this class align with your expectations?
comments: I did not expect to learn so much about soils.
All of the material we covered was aligned with my expectations.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of the course and how could it be improved?
comments: One of the strengths is that the schedule and frequency of visiting the property we work on are very flexible. Students can tailor the schedule and focused areas of their field trips based on the traits of their property and their objectives.

The course is extensive in its scope and immensely useful, but the way the material is delivered is not particularly digestible. Without previous courses in dendrology, in particular, I would imagine it would have been very difficult to do well on the exam. The course would be improved by breaking down the material more.
It can feel rushed but I don't know how to avoid that. The course does effectively condense a lot of material into one semester.

narratives.question_text: What advice would you give to a student considering taking this class?
comments: Prepare to loose some of your weekends. You will need to visit your property by Yale Myers freqently.
This course is front loaded in the semester and a lot of work, so make sure your other courses are not similarly set up to ensure you are not overwhelmed by your total workload.
